name: Ionic Bonding
what: This subtopic covers how metals and non-metals form ionic compounds through electron transfer. You will learn to predict ion charges, draw electron transfer diagrams, and write formulas for ionic compounds.
why: Ionic bonding explains how most salts and minerals form. Understanding electron transfer connects atomic structure to compound formation and explains why certain ratios of elements combine.

items.title: I can predict the charge of ions formed by main group elements
items.what: Metals lose electrons to form positive ions (cations). Non-metals gain electrons to form negative ions (anions). The charge equals the number of electrons transferred to achieve a full outer shell.
items.why: Predicting ion charges is essential for writing correct formulas and understanding why compounds have specific ratios of elements.
items.example: Magnesium (Group 2) loses 2 electrons to form Mg¬≤‚Å∫. Chlorine (Group 17) gains 1 electron to form Cl‚Åª.

items.title: I can explain the difference between cations and anions
items.what: Cations are positive ions formed when atoms lose electrons. Anions are negative ions formed when atoms gain electrons. The names come from the electrodes they move toward.
items.why: Distinguishing between cations and anions is fundamental to understanding ionic bonding and electrolysis.
items.example: Sodium atoms lose one electron to become Na‚Å∫ cations. Fluorine atoms gain one electron to become F‚Åª anions (called fluoride ions).

items.title: I can draw electron shell diagrams showing ionic bond formation
items.what: Draw the atoms, show electrons transferring from metal to non-metal, then show the resulting ions with their charges and electron arrangements matching a noble gas.
items.why: These diagrams provide visual evidence of how ionic bonds form and why specific ions result from specific atoms.
items.example: For NaCl: draw sodium (2,8,1) losing its outer electron to chlorine (2,8,7), resulting in Na‚Å∫ (2,8) and Cl‚Åª (2,8,8).

items.title: I can identify which noble gas an ion has the same electron configuration as
items.what: After forming ions, elements have the same number of electrons as a noble gas. This stable configuration is why atoms form ions in the first place.
items.why: Recognising noble gas configurations reinforces why specific charges form and connects ion formation to stability.
items.example: Na‚Å∫ has 10 electrons (2,8), the same as neon. Cl‚Åª has 18 electrons (2,8,8), the same as argon.

items.title: I can write formulas for ionic compounds using the crossover method
items.what: Write the ions with their charges. Cross over the charge numbers to become subscripts on the opposite ion. Simplify if needed. The compound must be electrically neutral.
items.why: Writing correct formulas is essential for describing compounds precisely and for balancing equations.
items.example: For magnesium chloride: Mg¬≤‚Å∫ and Cl‚Åª. Cross over: Mg‚ÇÅCl‚ÇÇ. The formula is MgCl‚ÇÇ (one magnesium ion for every two chloride ions).

items.title: I can explain why ionic compounds have high melting points
items.what: Ionic compounds contain strong electrostatic attractions between oppositely charged ions throughout the lattice. A lot of energy is needed to overcome these attractions.
items.why: Melting point relates directly to bond strength. High melting points of ionic compounds are evidence of strong ionic bonding.
items.example: Sodium chloride melts at 801¬∞C because the Na‚Å∫ and Cl‚Åª ions are held together by strong electrostatic forces that require significant energy to break.

items.title: I can explain why ionic compounds conduct electricity when molten or dissolved
items.what: Ionic compounds conduct electricity only when their ions are free to move. This occurs when the compound is melted or dissolved in water. Solid ionic compounds do not conduct.
items.why: Conductivity tests help identify ionic compounds and demonstrate that moving charged particles are required for electrical conduction.
items.example: Solid NaCl does not conduct electricity because ions are fixed in the lattice. Molten NaCl conducts because Na‚Å∫ and Cl‚Åª ions can move freely.
